title: AB 933
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature enacted the 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and NHTSA funding. The Legislature enacted a statewide 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and additional funding from NHTSA. The program allows courts to order individuals convicted of DUI offenses to participate in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of probation, parole, or sentence if certain criteria are met. The court may require a person arrested for DUI to enroll in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of release on bond if certain criteria are met. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege if they committed a violation within 10 years of a previous DUI conviction. Participation in the program may be required for a minimum of one year. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program for a minimum of one year. The program requires abstaining from alcohol or controlled substances, undergoing breath testing at least twice daily, and facing immediate sanctions for violations. The methodology must be evidence-based. Evaluation research confirms that the 24/7 Sobriety program produces positive results attributed to the program itself, peer-reviewed by experts, and endorsed by federal agencies. Participants may also be required to participate in other DUI programs. Testing methods for violations should be timely and effective. The court prioritizes testing methods for violations to be timely and effective. Participants must pay program costs based on their ability to pay. Programs cannot exceed 180 days unless the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs or fails to appear for a test. The court limits program length to 180 days unless the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs. The Office of Traffic Safety must include 24/7 Sobriety program details in its highway safety plan. The department will collect participant data uniformly. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code is amended to allow public inspection of department records related to vehicle registration, driver's license applications, convictions, and accident reports, with exceptions for confidentiality. The department in Sacramento will provide abstracts of convictions and accident reports for specific time periods: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for violations with two points, and 3 years for accidents and other violations. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports for specific time periods: 10 years for certain violations, 7 years for violations with two points, and 3 years for accidents and other violations. Suspensions and revocations of driving privileges are disclosed for three years following termination of the action, except for specific cases where disclosure is limited to the actual suspension period. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. Suspensions and revocations of driving privileges are disclosed for three years following termination of the action, except for specific cases where disclosure is limited to the actual suspension period. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. Personal information is only disclosed in compliance with the Driver’s Privacy Protection Act of 1994. Convictions of specific offenses are disclosed to courts and law enforcement agencies for 10 years from the date of the offense for penalty enforcement. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports for specific time periods. Convictions of Section 191.5 or subdivision (a) of Section 192.5 of the Penal Code punished as a felony are disclosed for penalty enforcement. Consent to use a driver's license number for insurance purposes is presumed if provided to an insurer, employer, or prospective employer. The insurance agent or broker can transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes and is not responsible for how the recipient handles the records. Prior to transmitting records, the broker or agent must obtain a written agreement from the insurer or third party to handle the records according to state and federal laws on fair credit reporting and privacy.
